He is no longer terrified, but still unsure of his situation and the intentions of the Beast People.

Prendick seems disturbed and scared by the events of this section.
He is still trying to figure out how to escape the island and is frustrated with Montgomery's behavior.
Prendick is devastated by the destruction of the boats and the death of Montgomery, and is now alone and vulnerable on the island.

Prendick has realized the danger he is in and is beginning to see the Beast People's rapid regression into more animal-like beings.
He is relieved to have escaped the island, but haunted by the memories of his experiences there.
He has found peace and protection in the glittering hosts of heaven and has withdrawn himself from the confusion of cities.
